metadata.case_name: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate represented by Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha v. Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate

facts.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee appointed as Assistant Medical Officer of Dimakuchi Tea Estate with effect from November 1, 1950, subject to satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

Appointment letter stated: While on probation, suitability for permanent employment considered; if unsuitable, seven days' notice terminating appointment; if misconduct, instant dismissal; if suitable at end, confirmed.
In February 1951, Dr. Banerjee given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.
On April 21, 1951, manager Mr. Booth terminated Dr. Banerjee's services effective April 22, 1951, with one month's salary in lieu of notice. No reasons given initially.
Dr. Banerjee inquired reasons; reply: reasons on medical side known to Dr. Cox; main reason deceitful addition to medical indent after signature.
Manager later stated discharge due to incompetence in medical duties, lack of knowledge of microscopical/lab work; faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock nearly causing paralysis.
Cause espoused by Mangaldai Circle of Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha; wrote to manager inquiring reasons.
Conciliation proceedings held unsuccessfully over termination.
Referred to Tripartite Appellate Board (Labour Commissioner, Assam; reps of Indian Tea Association and Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha); recommended reinstatement from date of discharge.
Management offered 28 months' salary/allowances in lieu of reinstatement; appellants did not agree.
Dr. Banerjee received Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left the tea garden.

Government of Assam notified on December 23, 1953 referring dispute to Shri U.K. Gohain (Additional District & Sessions Judge) under s.10(1)(c) IDA: Whether management justified in dismissing Dr. Banerjee? If not, entitled to reinstatement or other relief?
Tribunal held Dr. Banerjee not a workman; no industrial dispute; no jurisdiction.
Appeal to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta affirmed: dispute must be between employers and workmen.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on March 14, 1956, limited to whether dispute re non-workman falls within s.2(k) IDA.
Parties proceeded on footing Dr. Banerjee not a workman u/s 2(s) IDA (pre-1956 amendment).

legal_issues.text: Whether a dispute in relation to the termination of service of a person who is not a workman within the meaning of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, falls within the scope of the definition of 'industrial dispute' in s.2(k) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'of any person' in third part of s.2(k) is wide; not equated to 'workman'; dispute between employer and workmen connected with non-employment of Dr. Banerjee (non-workman) is industrial dispute.
Limitations on 'any person': real/substantial dispute where relief possible; relates to same establishment; person is employee/discharged/candidate; nexus via personal interest or labour welfare.
Dr. Banerjee in same establishment; discharged employee; workmen interested as he belonged to union; dismissal without charge/opportunity affects all workmen.

respondent_arguments.text: Dr. Banerjee not a workman u/s 2(s); no industrial dispute as must be between employers/workmen; Tribunal no jurisdiction.
'Any person' limited to workmen class (including discharged/future); no community of interest with supervisory staff.

court_reasoning.text: S.2(k) analysed in three parts: dispute/difference; between employers/employers, employers/workmen, workmen/workmen; connected with employment/non-employment/terms/conditions of labour of any person. 'Any person' not unlimited; read in context of Act's scheme/objects.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act regulates employer-workmen relations; promotes amity, settles disputes between specified parties.

court_reasoning.text: Literal wide reading leads to absurdities (e.g., dispute over District Judge's employment); must harmonise with objects (Maxwell on Statutes).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Limitations implicit: real dispute capable of relief; parties directly/substantially interested; relates to same establishment.

court_reasoning.text: 'Any person' means person in whose employment etc. workmen as class have direct/substantial interest/community of interest; not supervisory staff excluded from benefits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between workmen/non-workmen; Act confers benefits on workmen.

court_reasoning.text: Dr. Banerjee medical/technical staff, different category; no direct/substantial interest by workmen even if union member.
Sarkar J. (dissent): 'Any person' ordinary wide meaning includes non-workmen; no sufficient reason to restrict to workmen class; cases like Western India support.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispute between employer/workmen over non-workman's dismissal is industrial dispute.

holdings.text: Expression 'any person' in s.2(k) IDA subject to limitations: real dispute capable of settlement/adjudication; person must be one in whose employment/non-employment etc. parties (esp. workmen class) have direct/substantial interest/community of interest.
Dispute over Dr. Banerjee's termination not industrial dispute as no such interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: Absurd results of wide reading of 'any person'; crucial test: direct/substantial interest of workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Disputes re reinstatement/non-employment within s.2(k); 'any person' covers discharged workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U.P.
C.P. Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual dispute of workman within s.2(k).
Disputes between municipalities/employees analogous to trade/business.
Wide view of 'any person'; concerned discharged workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S.N. Modak
East India Industries (Madras) Ltd. v. Their Workmen
United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Kedar Nath Gupta
Prahlad Rai Oil Mills v. State of Uttar Pradesh

precedents_cited.relevance: Majority: includes non-workmen; minority: limited to employer/workmen class; Full Bench reversed to limit.

precedents_cited.case_name: George Hudson Ltd. v. Australian Timber Workers Union

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of industrial dispute/workman; authorities/procedure; binding nature of awards; strikes/lockouts; pendency restrictions; representation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trade Unions Act, 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of trade dispute differs due to broad 'workman'.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding that the dispute regarding termination of Dr. K.P. Banerjee, who was not a workman, did not constitute an industrial dispute under s.2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as workmen lacked direct or substantial interest therein. No order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: 'Industrial dispute' means any dispute or difference between employers and employers, or between employers and workmen, or between workmen and workmen, which is connected with the employment or non-employment or the terms of employment or with the conditions of labour, of any person.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The expression 'any person' in s.2(k) must be read subject to limitations: (1) real dispute capable of settlement/adjudication; (2) person in whose employment etc. parties have direct/substantial interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding narrowing scope of 'industrial dispute'.

key_quotes.text: The words of a statute... are to be understood in the sense in which they best harmonise with the subject of the enactment and the object which the Legislature has in view.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Dr. Banerjee being not a workman, his case is not one of an industrial dispute under the Industrial Disputes Act and... beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
